name: Legendary
description: All creatures of ancient myth, legend and lore are real  they've just been sealed away for thousands of years inside Pandora's Box, waiting... When a thief named Deckard is hired to steal an ancient artifact, he unwittingly triggers a war between man and myth.

reviews.review_text: Better than Aliens™: Colonial Marines.

An interesting game with some amazing visuals. For once we get a fresh take on battling monsters, instead of taking place in the far flung fantasy filled past of wizards or knights, or in a galaxy far far away in some doom wannabe, we get a game that lets us take on mythological creatures of the past in the modern world. This game does have bugs, its not perfect, and the controls are kind of shot. Some strange bugs encountered was that the sun in the sky would appear through objects or when in an enclosed room or tunnel and one gamebreaking bug at the end of the game. The game played with a keyboard and mouse is way to easy. The controller controls arent great they skate around and the look or aim seems to often fly all over. While normally I would hate that, this isnt a platformer where any precise jumps are required. In a way the bad controls added to the challenge. Somehow the floaty controls for aiming made me feel like I was there since noone would stay perfect in that situation with their aim.   Multiplayer is dead since gamespy is dead, but the story is fun, many of the visuals of the blown up burned out city are great. Def worth a playthrough and if its too easy just exit and change the difficulty.   To pass the elevator glitch that kills you at the end of the game go to 'C:\Users\USERNAME\Documents\My Games\Legendary\PandoraGame\Config' set framerate to 30, then play until the next checkpoint exit and set it back to 300.  Rating: 5/10 Value: $4.99

The well-known legend of Pandora’s Box demands much more than what Developer Spark created here. Also, it just doesn’t seem right that Deckard is capable of force pushing and draining life-energy, but utterly fails at simple jumping. The single-player campaign is quite short, but full of spectacular and varied scenes. It's a lot of fun, but too linear, and the use of generic weapons, imprecise controls and inconsistent graphics show a lack of fine-tuning.Legendary isn’t the most involved or technically excellent shooter out there, but it’s a fun change of pace with extremely satisfying combat.

For a game that came out in 2008, during a time when it had a lot to compete with in the shooter genre, Legendary was suprsingly good! There wasn't much to do with games then as AI was limited and graphics were too but the devs definately made a playable combination of diffculty and entertainment. If you like mythology and big, violent creatures tearing people apart, this game is for you. If you get bored VERY EASILY with linear gameplay, this game is not for you. It was 2008 when this came out, remember, there weren't a whole bunch of open ended games then.  If I could fix two things, I would have asked for more weapons/animus abilites and better collision detection.  There are times where you're running in a straight line to escape an enemy and you suddenly stop - not because you meant to but because your character got stuck on a penny-sized bump on the sidewalk or a plant. Seriously.  Other than those two minor hiccups, the game was great for what it was and when it was made. Over all, 8/10. 2 points off for aforementioned problems/issues.

This game feels like it is only half finished. From the storyboards used as cutscenes, to the sticky controls (I use an xbox 360 wired controller and the analogue controls are extremely jerky) this game looks as though it could have been a real gem but constantly falls short.   There are times when your character literally get's stuck on a ramp or a step, because the programmers haven't made the blocks fit properly. The controls regularly let you down as well, such as the jump (which is the worst jump feature I have ever seen, it's practically a hop) which you can press and time to climb over something and yet you simply don't.   The story starts of well, but by the end it is clear that the writyers have no real idea what they are doing and it pretty much goes to hell quickly. The missions have you jumping around the globe in an instant and the storyboard cutscenes do a really poor job of showing you any sort of time passing.   The ending of the game just sort of happens as well. It doesn't really explain (at least very well) what your role is in stopping things, you just have to use your powers to overcharge a computer that is connected to Pandora's Box..... Which personally I find pretty funny considering this is based on a Greek myth and so I would have figured that there would have been a more magical and godly way to close the box, but apparently not.   Finally, the main reason I am leaving a negative review....  I could have lived with everything I have said up until this point and whilst I wouldn't have recommended the game, I wouldn't have complained either. However, right at the end of the game there is an elevator that is simply broken. You stand in the Elevator to go to the final platform, and your character falls straight through and into nothing, seeing the worldspace dissappear into black above you. I looked this up and it is a known issue that has been complained about since what I am assuming is release (2012). There are posts that claim there are ways to fix it, but none of these fixes worked for me. Frankly though, I shouldn't have to fix a game that has been out for at least 4 years anyway. This is a gamebreaking bug and the developer has quite literally ignored it and ignored the complaints that it has triggered. This is unacceptable and frankly it is disgusting. The only way I could complete the game was by using a noclipping (walk through walls) hack that someone on the forums suggested. This led me to wander through the world space until I found the next trigger point to be able to continue the mission. Again, this is pathetic and unacceptable.   Do not buy this game. Whether it is £10 or 1p, I would not recommend paying for a game that is riddled with bugs and where the developer clearly doesn't care. Save your money and buy something from a studio that cares about the product that they release.

What blows me away in the game industry is the time, effort, and dedication teams make to their craft. Oftentimes, it seems that teams who are so passionate about their projects for some reason or another just miss the mark. This is one of those occasions. The dev diaries, trailers, promotional materials all made this game seem extremely promising. Pandora's Box is opened and mythical creatures from Greek myths roam the lands in modern-day New York (I think?). Sounds cool, sounds fun, sounds 'fresh' as the marketing and branding teams wants you to think.  Do not, under any circumstances, purchase this game. This goes on the 'why do I own this?' list of my collection. This shooter came out in the aftermath of a shooting rennaisance - Halo, Call of Duty(s), Battlefield(s), amongst many others - and yet couldn't take the queues from games that know how to make shooters and make a decent clone. A brief, and kind, summary:  -poor controls -awful graphics -forgettable, unrelatable, and despicable protagonist -poor writing -absolutely no motivation for your actions  I would go more into depth with flowery prose, but I just want to distance myself from this game as soon as possible. I know many, many people spent years of their lives making this thing come together. I really wish they could have spent that time on a project that was enjoyable.  Just... don't do it. You're better off using your money to wax your nether regions - it'll be more pleasurable.

The protagonist Charles Decard opens Pandora's Box, unaware of its nature, unleashing all kinds of mythological creatures rampaging throughout the world. Decard has to kill the monsters from various myths and save the world.  This has been a very pleasant surprise for me. The story is very cliche really and the game could do with a bit of polish. The sceneries and pacing however really make this game. In the beginning a great golem made from cars and wreckage roams through NYC, destroying everything in its path. Later Decard has to defeat a giant Kraken in London.  The campaign is quite short, only around 7 hours, but that is a good thing: The developers didn't reuse and repeat the sceneries over and over. Instead I always had the feeling of actually going forward, something other arguably better games like Doom 3 did not manage.  For the price the game is definetively recommended.

Not as bad as the reviews say. I went into it expecting a pretty terrible shooter with uninspired gameplay and a forgettable story.  It's a fairly straightforward shooter with some annoying bits and poor difficulty tuning. However, the shooter elements are pretty good, and while the game tries a bit too hard on the horror-like elements, it does a good job of making the various monsters pretty intimidating.  The actual story started out semi-decent, then evolved rapidly into something really stupid, then ended pretty well. It's not something to write home about but the ending was nice.  Overall it's not bad even if it is kinda short (5-6 hours). Worth a look if it's on sale and you want to waste a few hours having fun shooting mythological creatures. I advise avoiding the hard difficulty setting, and even turning it down to easy if the challenges get annoying. The difficulty is poorly tuned and it is a bit more fun on easy than it is on other difficulty settings.

If it's on sale- I bought it for $0.74- definitely worth the price. I wouldn't spring more than maybe $2 or $3 for it though. It's fun enough to hold your attention, and it's different enough to be intriguing. Worth a few hours of your time, and if you don't like it, you're only out a buck.  PROS Intriguing story.  Just enough interactive elements to make it somewhat immersive.  A different take on combat than you sometimes see. For example, some beasties you might have to injure in a very specific way in combat or after they are felled to win.   It's different, and you'll have to think on what you know of mythology to really get it, which makes the plot that much more immersive. Some of the environment is destructable and has to be destroyed to logically solve a puzzle to get to the next stage.  CONS Somewhat on rails as you're essentially guided from one area to another by the environment.   The intrigue is taken away if you read the notes on the creatures and such as they're somewhat spoilerific.   Although much of the environment is interactive or destructable, enough of it isn't that it's easy to forget to try to puzzle through it as if it were a real-life or Dungeons and Dragons type game.

I found myself running around with the rocket launcher whenever i was able to get my hands on it just to handle the gryphins from time to time :)  The graphics are dated compared to modern times but still stand apart and there are noticible bugs, such as you cant jump and move forward over a obstacle you have to run then jump far away not to get stuck.
